citation.article-title: Nocardioides aestuarii sp. nov., isolated from tidal flat sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Nocardioides aestuarii sp. nov.
Nocardioides aestuarii (aes.tu′ar.i.i. N.L. gen. n. aestuarii of the tidal flat).
Cells are non-motile rods of approximately 0·9–2·1×0·3–0·4 μm.
Colonies on MA are ivory, circular, convex, glistening, opaque and butyraceous and have an entire margin.
Colonies are approximately 0·5–1 mm in diameter after 3 days on MA at 30 °C; they reach the maximum diameter of 1–2 mm after 5 days.
Substrate or aerial mycelium is not observed.
Grows at 20–35 °C, pH 6–10 and 0–8 % (w/v) NaCl; optimal growth at 30 °C, pH 7 and 0–2 % (w/v) NaCl.
Major fatty acids are iso-16 : 0 (52·0 %) and iso-16 : 1 H (14·5 %).

In addition, 17 : 1ω8c (7·0 %), 10Me-17 : 0 (3·1 %), 18 : 1ω9c (2·7 %), iso-14 : 0 (1·8 %), anteiso-17 : 0 (1·8 %), 10 : 0 (1·4 %), 10Me-16 : 0 (1·3 %), anteiso-15 : 0 (1·3 %), iso-15 : 0 (1·2 %) and a mixture of iso-15 : 0 2-OH and 16 : 1ω7c (1·3 %; MIDI system cannot differentiate these two fatty acids) are present.
Trace amount of tuberculostearic acid (0·3 %) also exists.
Results of API 20NE, API ZYM kits, decomposition of high-molecular-weight substrates and carbon source utilization are given in Table 1.
Isolated from sediment of getbol (tidal flat) in Ganghwa Island, Korea (37°36′22·3″N, 126°22′59·4″E).
